If solutions can be found in that way by by-passing all these difficult, intractable problems of management and control, which seem so irrelevant to the children who never can see what all this is about, then let us find it in that way.

I hope the Minister will not be dogmatic about this and if the community school proposal does produce a willingness to co-operate and if that co-operation will solve the problem we should accept that solution rather than try to push a particular, rigidly-structured answer to the problem. In many cases it will not: there are cases where co-operation is impossible; the geographical distance is too great or there may be such an unwillingness to co-operate in some cases that nothing will knock together the heads of the people concerned and perhaps some more drastic solution is then necessary. Each case should be treated on its merits.

Here, as everywhere else, the problem has been aggravated by the failure to get across its nature to the people concerned. In talking about education in different parts of the country I find that I am really having to do the Minister's job. Instead of being able to get on with criticising the Minister's policies which, politically, would be much more beneficial from my point of view —and there is much to criticise—I find myself, as in Waterford the other night, spending a long time trying to explain to people what the Minister is trying to achieve, why he is trying to do so, why the objective is a good one, and where it has gone wrong. Sometimes my local party supporters are a little critical of the fact that I seem to be acting as the spokesman of the Minister rather than presenting his policies but the truth is that if you are to get people to help to solve these problems, they must understand them. The Minister has failed to get across what the problem is.

I believe in reason. I know I am an optimist to believe that reason prevails but ultimately it does prevail. It is very hard work, as in the case of the dialogue of Deputy Thornley and myself with the Minister over community schools but, even there, reason prevailed. It only took nine months, a reasonable gestation period for anything reasonable to emerge. If you are to persuade people to make drastic changes where their loyalties are involved they must understand the reasons. It is quite clear to me, in going around the country, that not only do the parents, never mind the students, not understand the problems but that the school managers and teachers very often do not understand what the Minister is trying to do. Because there has never been a White Paper, never any discussion of policy proper and the Minister even in his opening speech here did not deal really with these basic issues, they have never had it put to them what the problem is. I am convinced that if from the beginning the Minister had set out the problem of parity of esteem, the problem of range of subjects in terms that were not capable of the kind of distortion there was in the article to which I referred earlier, and if it were put across in peaceful dialogue with the people concerned and it was put up to them: “Are not these good objectives? Do you not agree they are reasonable?” they would have to agree. If you then put to them: “How do you see them being achieved in your context?” and let them come up with the answer, requiring only that the answer should conform to the criterion which they themselves have accepted in argument as reasonable, you would have solved many of these problems much quicker and with much less bitterness and hostility and tension. Instead, no adequate explanation was given of what the problem was and a solution to a problem that nobody recognised was propounded, totally rigid and inflexible, to be imposed on people whether they liked it or not.

I know the Minister does not see it that way and that he thinks I am being unfair and exaggerating. To make one's point one must always exaggerate, at least in emphasis if not in words, but fundamentally I am right. Fundamentally, this has been the difficulty. It is not a disagreement in principle over the policy pursued; it has been a political failure to get it across. Here the Minister is at fault in putting the burden of this on civil servants. It is quite wrong to send a civil servant out to carry out the political function of persuading people to accept a political solution to a problem of this kind. That is not a civil servant's function. His job is to advise the Minister as to what the solution is; it is the Minister's job to sell it. The reason we have a Minister and a Parliamentary Secretary—and I am glad we have both; the Department badly need two —is to have the personnel to go around and do this job. The Minister must be able to get away from his desk sufficiently to do the job. I know it is tough. I was sorry for the Parliamentary Secretary in Tallaght where he was nearly torn to pieces by the crowd. My sympathies were with him to a large extent up to the point where he read out a bit of a letter and said: “There is nothing more of interest to you in it” and was forced to read the remainder of it to discover that it said the opposite to the first part.

Speaker.P: There must have been one occasion when you did not defend him?

On the particular issue of the letter, I certainly did not. I was horrified at behaviour which I thought totally uncharacteristic of the Parliamentary Secretary and could only be a mental aberration of some kind on the part of somebody of his integrity. However, I was sorry for him up to that point.

Although it is a tough job and although you may be torn to pieces by the people present that is precisely why the Minister and the Parliamentary Secretary must do it themselves. It is intolerable to put a civil servant in that position and he will not be able to do the job that is necessary. He has not been trained to sell something like a public relations officer and we are public relations officers whether good, bad or indifferent. This is a political job. It was quite wrong of the Minister to do that and it is not the tradition in other Departments. There are some Departments where this has happened. There was the notorious case where the secretary of the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries was assigned to give a Press conference denouncing the NFA on behalf of his Minister which was quite a wrong thing to do and it was frowned on within the Civil Service. Quite rightly, there was much adverse comment on it in the Civil Service.

MainHeading.P: Other Departments do not allow this to happen. I shall not name them as it could be embarrassing to do so but I know one Department where the Minister thought that a civil servant should go around the country doing the same kind of job as the Minister here has required his civil servants to do, selling a particular scheme. I shall only say that as a result of advice given a contrary decision was taken and I respect the Minister for having listened to that advice and taken it. I am sorry it was not done in the Department of Education. However, we all make mistakes and I am sure the Minister will not make that mistake again and that in future he or his Parliamentary Secretary will undertake the political work of the Department and not impose it on civil servants who should not be forced to do it.

I have been dealing with all this under the heading of the effective use of resources and rationalisation. I have not quite finished yet. I now come to deal with the third point to which I referred earlier, the question of standards. I shall not dwell on it at any great length but there are a few points I want to make. First, I do not think membership of the EEC has enormously significant direct implications for Irish education. Twice recently I was asked to speak on Irish education within the EEC. I know I disappointed the audience, on one occasion certainly, and I think on both, by saying that there are not that many implications. Of course, there are indirect implications because EEC membership will transform this country in a number of ways. This must have implications for education. The only direct implications which are totally direct are the implications for third level professional education of the equivalence of diplomas and qualifications arising out of the free movement of labour and the right of establishment. There is a problem there.

I should like the Minister to say something about this. I do not think the implications for us are very great but we shall be required under the EEC legislation, if our professional people are to have the right to establish themselves in other countries with free movement of labour, and the right to move as workers and employees, to ensure that our “standards”—I put that in inverted commas—in these professional qualifications are the same as in other EEC countries. This will be a legal requirement. The legislation concerned, as far as I know, has not yet been enacted in any instance, or at most in one, but virtually all of it is now in train and is known. Details of the broad shape it will take are publicly known. I know it is a slow process to get it through. I do not think the agricultural science provisions have been published yet although I have succeeded in acquiring a copy of them. The trend in legislation is to require that courses will be of the same length. The question of standards has been interpreted very crudely. The obvious difficulty of measuring standards, except objectively, has proved a little too much and so generally the line taken is that courses must be courses of not less than four years, four and a half years or five years.

I would ask the Minister to tell us, when replying, in which of the professions is the length of course as required by the legislation proposed in the EEC, as published, longer than our present courses and which of the courses are affected. I know of some of them myself, but I do not think I have a complete picture. There is, I think, some problem in the case of pharmacy. I would not from recollection mention the others but there are one or two other cases where courses may need to be slightly lengthened. I should like the Minister to tell the House whether he has been in touch with the professional bodies concerned because, frankly, I have raised this here over two years in this House with various Ministers and I have the impression that the various professions were never approached by any Government Department to be told the implications of this legislation. I myself have actually written to them all and provided information for a number of them and, in fact, I have done some research for some of them when they wanted further details. This is a job the Government should be doing and I should like to know from the Minister has he been in touch with the professions and made them aware of the implications involved and where, in fact, are the implications significant.

Again, in the case of pharmacy, not only will there be a need to lengthen the course but the actual content of the course will be determined by these regulations. As I understand it, the content of the course—I have the details at home—is laid down on the basis that something like two-thirds of the total number of hours in the four years—I think it is a four-year course—is allocated to specific subjects and sub-subjects, down to the detail of not less than 20 hours practical and 20 hours theoretical microbiology, for example. Not all the time is allocated; one-third is left free so that each country can add on to these 20 hours as much as it wishes in individual subjects. There is a fairly stringent programme proposed.

I hope the Department has been keeping in touch with all this. I hope it has been in touch with the professions concerned and notified them of what is involved. In my contacts with the professions I have never had the slightest inkling from any of them that anyone has approached them on the subject except myself. The Minister has a duty here and would be doing only his duty if he kept au fait with the developments in the position here and with the professions concerned. Apart from that, and I do not think this will cause much worry, one or two will be lengthened. There is no direct impact of EEC membership on education in the sense of legislation requiring a change in the educational system; there is, of course, an indirect impact to which I referred earlier on the question of languages. That whole question will have to be dealt with. Modern continental languages will become much more important. Beyond that, all one can say is that the more competitive environment at home that our people will face is one which will mean that any deficiencies in our educational system will be more serious than they have been hitherto.

We have in the past been extraordinarily unconcerned in the export of our young people without proper education. I hope that attitude of unconcern is changing. Hitherto we have not had to worry too much about our position domestically because we have not had to face competition domestically, but we will be moving into a much more open environment and, in that environment, the question of standards at home as well as the standards of those who emigrate will be important.

We have problems here at each level, one of which I have dealt with already. We have at the primary level problems posed by large classes in urban areas and small schools in rural areas. These have implications for standards. The Minister is tackling them but, as I said, progress is disturbingly slow and he has not really fully explained why. We have also a problem—I know this is a sensitive area and particularly sensitive for the Minister himself—that we have to face as a fact and that is that in this country, as distinct from our near neighbour, we have to teach two languages in the primary schools. There is no dissent from this policy. No one suggests we should not teach Irish as well as English in the primary schools.

There will be some problems to be considered in the context of reunification. Clearly, we are not intending to impose this on the primary schoolchildren in Northern Ireland and the rationality in a united Ireland of insisting on Irish being taught in a primary school in Monaghan but not in a primary school next door in Armagh may be in doubt. Leaving the problems of reunification on one side, at this stage, and in the present context, nobody is proposing any change in the system. We all recognise that the primary school is a single stream school. There is not a choice of subjects—there cannot be—and you, therefore, either teach Irish or you do not and the predominant view of people in this part of the country is that they want their children in the primary schools to be taught Irish. No choice is possible: as between teaching it and not teaching it, we believe in teaching it. That is not an issue.

We have, however, to face the fact that up to some years ago the time given to Irish was so overwhelming that it created a problem of inadequate time for other subjects. I think this has changed. I think the Minister, without making any announcement and with no fanfare of trumpets at any Fianna Fáil Ard-Fheis, has, in fact, encouraged, or permitted, the schools to reduce the predominant time given to Irish to a more reasonable level and the result of that is that the time available for other subjects has been raised somewhat, but it is still very far away from the kind of time that is available for them in, for example. Northern Ireland and Britain. We must face the fact that this is a problem. There is no use in closing our eyes to it.

Up to about 1963, with our shorter school year, the actual volume of teaching in our primary schools over the whole life of the child in terms of teacher contact hours in the case of English, arithmetic and other subjects was about half what it was in the schools in Northern Ireland and Britain. No amount of good teaching, and there is plenty of good teaching in Irish primary schools, could make up for that or do anything other than create a situation where, in those circumstances, Irish children emerged from school less well equipped in English, arithmetic, and other subjects which play a growing part in the primary curriculum, than did the children in Northern Ireland and Britain.

To state that is to state a fact. It is not to state anything hostile to the Irish language and I am not suggesting for a moment it should not be taught, but it has been necessary to try to mitigate this problem, which is inherent in this bilingual country, which neither Britain nor Northern Ireland is, by making some changes and I should like to hear from the Minister what progress there has been in this. The Minister ought to tell us what has been achieved. I think the time given to Irish is not now so overwhelming and the time given to other subjects has increased and the problems of retardation, so ably illustrated in Dr. McNamara's Bill of Rights book, must have been somewhat reduced over this period, though they still exist. I would like the Minister to tell us what progress has been made there. Let him not be too coy about it. He will not be replying to this debate until after the Fianna Fáil Ard-Fheis, so nothing he says will be used in evidence against him on that occasion.

I congratulate the Minister on the new curriculum. He is right in saying that nothing in Irish education in recent years has received such universal approval. I think this is true. I have seen no criticism of it and nothing but commendation from everyone, and I am very glad to see provision being made to ensure the effective introduction of the new curriculum. The proposals made are satisfactory and the allocation of £250,000 for this period of the current year is a beginning. Of course, when you spread that over all the schools, it comes out a very small sum. The Minister did tell us what the sums were—he did not hide the fact. A sum of £250,000 spread in this way yields, in the case of a two-teacher school, £20, which is a small sum but it is a beginning, and I am very glad, indeed, that he has introduced this. This, with the introduction of the teacher centres, will certainly, with the other measures taken, help to ensure that the new curriculum is introduced as rapidly and as effectively as possible.

At secondary level, the problem of standards is one which is partly a problem of the size of schools, as I mentioned already, but there are other aspects to which I should like to refer. There is an aspect which we do not hear much of nowadays but it is an issue which we have to concern ourselves with, that is, the extent to which we are approaching a point where the teachers of a subject in these schools or, perhaps, to start with, at senior cycle level in these schools, do have a qualification in the subject in question. Other countries manage to have this arrangement. Why cannot we? Of course, I can see that any change here takes time—nothing like this can be done overnight—but what progress are we making towards it? I have heard nothing of progress in this connection for a long time past and I am not clear that we are making any progress.

The Minister should tell us if we are, how soon he expects to reach the point at which we will have a situation in which children in, say, senior cycle at least are taught by somebody with a degree in the subject. That is not too much to ask. We go on then beyond that to the point where children in junior and senior cycle are taught by people with a degree in the subject and beyond that to the point at which people in senior cycle at honours level are taught by people with honours degrees. These are different stages. Are we making progress to these stages and, if so, at what rate and when do we hope to reach each of these stages? We cannot hope to produce people as well educated as in other countries if they are not given the opportunities which children in other countries have. In other countries provision of this kind exists, these requirements exist, and it is possible to fulfil them and I would ask the Minister to tell us something about any progress made in this connection.

On one particular and specific aspect of standards which has come up recently I should like to say a word, especially on the teaching of French. I understand—again the Minister's speech does not reveal anything on this—a concession has been made on this question of the teaching of French in the schools about which I certainly have received representations. The failure to provide for an oral can have very bad effects, indeed, and I have spoken to teachers who have told me their own experience, that because they were encouraged to undertake all-type teaching and no oral examination was provided, they got into the position in which the children best at French failed while those less good at French did better. Any Department of Education which so manages its affairs as regards encouraging a development and not providing for it in the examination system as to have that result deserves some criticism, to put it no higher than that. I understand that the Minister has made a change here and there is going to be an option this year of an examination for children who are being taught in the two different ways. Is this correct?

Speaker.P: Yes.

I am very glad that is being done because it was certainly a very backward step not to make provision for it before. I hope— I have not had a chance to check out the reactions on this—that it does meet the needs of the situation and if it does not, I shall be back later to the Minister further on it, but it seems to me prima facie that what the Minister has done may help to ease the situation at this time. But let us be clear about this: no matter what the logistic problems are, if we are going to teach spoken languages in this country—our own native Irish language and the other languages, the languages which our people are going to need—we must be prepared to gear ourselves to the oral teaching and oral examining. For many people the practical need for languages is a need to be able to speak the language. There are certain people who want to have a literary knowledge and a total command of the language, but for practical purpose the great bulk of our people want to be in the position that they can speak freely to people in another country in their own language, and we have made extraordinarily slow progress towards that. I hope the Minister will be able to ensure that we do get to the point where the oral side is adequately examined in all these subjects and that we do not have the kind of situation created by this recent difficulty that has arisen.

MainHeading.P: I think those are the main points I wanted to make in regard to standards. I mentioned earlier the question of this age 12 requirement and I mentioned before the extraordinary results that has had. Where you have a preparatory school attached to a secondary school, you can get a situation where the brighter children in the preparatory school are the youngest in their classes, and when they come to the stage of going to the secondary school, if they go to the secondary school, the Minister will not allow them to be counted for grant purposes and, therefore, they are kept back. The secondary school may be short of numbers for grant purposes in some cases and they get more pupils in, and then promote the less able children into the secondary school so as to get the grant for the secondary school. Any system of assistance to education from a Government that encourages a school to promote the less able children and to keep the others back is a lunatic system. I put this to the Minister before and I hope he will see the need for a radical change in this. Of course, schools should not behave in that way, and most of them do not, but some are so pressed financially, especially those conned into the new free scheme without being able to find the resources to cope with it, that under great pressure they may behave in this way. It is all wrong that children should be held back at this particular stage.

I come now to the question of equality of opportunity in education —the fourth of the main issues I want to deal with. Here we have a number of different problems. Some of them I have dealt with already in dealing with other aspects of education. I have dealt with the small schools but one aspect I should like to deal with now relates to the senior cycle. I think that the Union of Students in Ireland are right in pressing for an extension of the grant system and right in seeking that the anomalies of the present scheme be eliminated and I hope the Minister will be able to do that quickly. I think they are right in general to seek to have the scheme extended to all students and assimilate the grant level with the entrance level but I think there may be a failure in emphasis here. I think our problem of equality of education at the moment is really lower down the line than at university level. Most people of ability who manage to get through from a disadvantaged home background from preparatory to secondary, through secondary up to senior cycle and who manage to stay on at school, despite the financial problems this causes for their parents, if they are that good very often do quite well, get a grant and get on to the university or the technical or training college, as the case may be.

Of course, it would be better if the grants were given at two honours rather than four honours level, but there are many people who do not get as far as doing the leaving certificate, and one feature of Fine Gael policy I very much regret the Minister did not adopt, when he adopted in the case of basic grants a somewhat different approach, was a proposal for grants at senior cycle level. I think this is important. In my own practical experience as a Deputy, I find myself faced with tragic cases, and, unfortunately, I come across too few of the cases that exist—they do not all come to one's attention—cases where, especially if the mother has been deserted by the husband, who is an alcoholic or has some problem of that kind, and there is a problem of earning capacity or illness among children. I had one case recently where the eldest child has to be kept at home to earn or to look after the other children because there is not enough money for the purpose, because the income of the family is so low. There was the case last year of a girl who had eight honours in her intermediate certificate. The mother had been deserted by the father and, although she realised the importance of education, she did not consider that it would be possible for her to allow her daughter to continue at school, the family having hardly enough to eat. She had decided to put her to work in a launderette. However, on the advice of the local priest, I suggested to the mother that the girl return to school and that younger children in the family, boys of 14 or 15 years of age, would take part-time evening work in a bar. That was not an ideal solution, but it meant that all the children were able to continue at school. The boys are very clever and are doing extremely well at vocational school. When there are so many problems of this nature, it is obvious that something must be done. A brilliant child coming from a disadvantaged home who for some financial reason is kept from school is not only a personal tragedy but a national tragedy. The contribution of that human being to the future of this country is being inhibited and the individual personal development of the child is being prevented. We have a national duty to deal with the problem. In financial terms, in so far as numbers are concerned, it is not a very major problem. I ask the Minister to find some solution to it.

I am sure the Minister will agree with me that it is less than ideal for a TD to be advising a mother in the circumstances I have mentioned to send children of 14 or 15 years of age to work in a pub. There is something wrong when we have to do so. There should be some scheme—of a discretionary nature, if necessary, but preferably on a more general basis— whereby when people's incomes are below a certain level a small grant can be made available. In our policy on education which was published five or six years ago we proposed that a grant of up to £100 a year be paid in necessitous cases. That amount may not seem very much but it could make all the difference to, say, a deserted wife living on £7 or £8 a week for herself and her children in deciding whether to allow a child to continue at school. The figure now should be £175 a year. Something in the region of £3 or £4 a week would be appropriate in relation to what we proposed in 1966 and appropriate in relation to the needs of the situation. This should take priority over the USI scheme, because unless children can be enabled to complete the senior cycle and obtain the required number of honours in the leaving certificate they will never have a chance of getting near a university. There is a danger that we provide more funds which go increasingly to middle-class people to enable them to educate their children. This is not solving the problem of the disadvantaged children who come from working class homes, particularly in the city.

As the Minister is aware the whole trend of educational thinking in recent years has been towards the recognition that one does not achieve equality of opportunity simply by providing grants that are available equally to everybody. Children coming from homes that are deprived culturally, as are so many homes in Ireland because of the class system we have inherited, are at such a disadvantage that unless more resources are available for them than for any middle-class child there will never be equality of opportunity.

No doubt the Minister has read the report of the conference of educational administrators that was held in Paris in 1970—the second of the two major OECD conferences on education that have been held, the first having been held in the 1960s. I considered this report to have been so worthwhile as to warrant my summarising it with some comments in The Irish Times. I found the document to be a very striking one. It was the result of civil servants from the educational departments of European countries and of North America and, I think, of Japan discussing educational policy.

One does not think of administrators in the Department of Education as socialist revolutionaries but when one reads this particular document carefully one realises, first, that their policies of the 1960s have failed and that the giving of grants does not resolve anything but enables people who start with a greater advantage to take more advantage of that position and to get further ahead. There is a very interesting graph in that report showing the attainment of children in rural schools in the US, Negro children and white children. This graph shows that, by measurements of aptitude tests, Negro children are fractionally behind white children, that there is a 10 per cent difference but that by the time they have finished school the difference is 30 per cent. More education that is given equally, without giving more attention to those most in need of it, only enables the better equipped child to make more progress. The consequence of these broad policies of grants given equally to everybody has been to increase educational inequality. This is the conclusion reached from all the studies carried out by these education administrators from all these countries. What was most interesting of all was their ultimate conclusion that there is need to put in extra effort where disadvantaged children are concerned. Fundamentally, what they were saying was that, with our present class system within the capitalist system, they did not think the problem could be solved at all. I found that to be an interesting conclusion to come from a body of men who are scarcely thought of as revolutionary. We should learn from that report and not always be ten years behind in wisdom.

We must begin to think. The Rutland Street experiment is a case in point, and I congratulate the Minister on it. Perhaps he will let us have some word of the progress being made and also whether there are any interim results from it that will enable us to begin to reorientate our educational polices more acceptably. We must begin to think in terms of an unequal allocation of educational resources with extra resources being put into the schools in which the majority of children come from educationally deprived backgrounds. In this way we would be doing our best to eliminate the problems that have resulted from the class system we have inherited.

I should like to say a few words on the special aspect of equality of opportunity in so far as the Protestant schools here are concerned. I discussed this at length on the last debate and I read out the ridiculously detailed means test requirement for Protestants to enable them to get some assistance towards reducing the fees in their schools. That is all they got from free education. If they are farmers they are required to fill up forms that constitute the most comprehensive farm accounts I have ever seen. That system is unsatisfactory. I emphasise that point here, because from conversations I have had with a senior ecclesiastic it is clear that, having read my speech in the paper, but not in the Dáil Official Report, the result was that he got the wrong end of the stick as to what I said and I was accused of having said that our system of grants discriminated against Protestants. Of course, it does not. If he had read my speech in full, he would have realised that what I said was that our system discriminates in favour of Protestants in that more money per head is available to Protestants; but because of the fact that Protestants have not got the enormous untold advantages of the system of religious orders in planning education and in ploughing their salaries back into education, the money the Government give, although Protestants get a little more of it than Catholics, is insufficient to enable them to provide free education. Even with discrimination in favour of Protestants financially, the effect on them is that they are discriminated against by the system and there is no free education in many areas for them but only reduced-fee education on a means test basis.

The Minister has tried to meet this problem in centres like Dublin and Cork by establishing Protestant comprehensive schools. I can see why he has done this and, possibly, it is the right answer. If we overcome the problem regarding Protestant comprehensive schools in Dublin or Cork, will it be possible to reallocate the funds available to the Protestant schools in the rest of the country to enable them to provide free education? The distribution of the Protestant community in Dublin and Cork is such that this may solve numerically a large proportion of the problem, but there are Protestants throughout the country who are at a disadvantage under the present system. Does the Minister see the possibility of getting over the situation that exists through no fault of anybody where, even with discrimination in favour of Protestants as regards extra finance, nevertheless they do not have free education? We look forward to proposals on this matter because it is a source of great irritation among the Protestant community. They appreciate they are not being treated in an unfair way; in fact, they are getting more than their share and the hostility is directed more at their own co-religionists who organise the means test scheme than at the Government.

The last of my five points dealing with the general educational philosophy is the question of variety. I do not propose to deal with this matter at length because I have referred to it previously in relation to the choice of subjects. On the question of choice of schools I realise that there are two points of view. It is a fact that if you have schools large enough to allow choice of subjects it will mean that there will be less choice of schools.

We should not reject the desirability of a choice of schools where this is possible. In the new suburbs, such as Tallaght and Blanchardstown, I am not enamoured of the idea of establishing community schools on a vast scale with approximately 1,600 pupils. I should prefer if these communities were planned so that there might be sub-communities within them, and that for each area with a certain population, which would be likely to produce a secondary school population of a certain number after a number of years, the area should be planned so that it would have its own subcommunity school.

The idea of planning one community school for Tallaght, which will have a population of approximately 136,000, is nonsense. To make such a vast suburb a desirable place in which to live it will be necessary to break it down into subunits. In this way people could live in an area which provided its own facilities, although naturally they could go to a central shopping centre and to a central area for the kind of services that could only be provided for such a large number of people. Ideally in each neighbourhood there would be essential services; there could be the neighbourhood primary school covering a small area, not like the huge primary school at Crumlin, for instance, where the children feel that they are merely ciphers. Certainly, they are not treated as ciphers by the teachers and the religious orders who do wonderful work, but the sheer size of the institution can intimidate the children.

We should plan the new towns in such a way that the primary and post-primary schools do not need to be larger than is necessary to achieve economy. I hope that in time there will be in Tallaght a number of primary and post-primary schools. If for some reason parents do not like the nearest community school it should be possible for them to transfer their children to another school. In offering a choice of this kind we should try to avoid any perpetuation of the dichotomy between the secondary and vocational schools, but it is better to have several schools rather than one enormous community school. We should avoid having larger institutions than is necessary for sound economic and educational reasons.

I have a number of individual points to make which do not fit into the structure of the five main issues with which I have been dealing. First, with regard to post-primary schools, many of them are in financial difficulty. In the enthusiasm generated by the Minister's energetic predecessor, the late Deputy Donough O'Malley, many schools joined in the free scheme, but they could not afford it. The free scheme gave them after a year or two an extra £25 per head by way of grant. That could not meet the problem of schools whose scale of expenditure at that time was such that fees had to be charged. In some instances fees of £30 to £60 were charged, although it should be pointed out that those schools were not making any profit. At that time the per capita cost in secondary schools ranged from £60 up to £130. The amount that was paid through the teacher's salary, incremental scheme, and the existing grants was such that on average schools received approximately £ 50 to £60 from the Government. This enabled many schools which were operating on a low level of costs, with perhaps an unfavourable teacher-student ratio, to charge minimal fees of £12—even in some cases many of the schools provided free education for 25 per cent of their pupils.

The schools whose cost level was above £60 per year, not due to their extravagance but because they provided a better teacher-student ratio and better amenities with regard to library and playing facilities, could not come into the scheme without loss if they received only £25 per head from the Government. Many of them came into the scheme because there was a mood of antipathy to the idea of having two classes of education—the fee-paying and the free—and many of the schools did not want to be part of a snob school system. In some instances they came into the scheme on the basis that they would ask parents to make voluntary contributions over a number of years to pay off their debts. In the enthusiasm of the moment the parents agreed to this but, predictably, the schools have got into difficulties. The new parents do not see why they should be asked to pay off some kind of debt incurred in previous years and a situation has arisen where the schools are not collecting these voluntary payments in sufficient amounts. Parents are increasingly resentful about this voluntary payment, which in some cases is great. I was told recently of a case where the voluntary payment was £95 per year; I cannot verify this because I was not given sufficient details but I was astonished at the figure. Parents who have some children attending school would find it impossible to pay this sum, especially when it is an obligation in whose incurring they had no role.

I should like the Minister to let us know the scale of this problem. I asked him a question on this matter before, but he dismissed it as not being his job. His Department should know how many of the schools are collecting voluntary contributions, the amount involved and what proportion the parents are paying. I hope the Minister will look into this matter because it is causing hardship to parents and schools. He should consider if some scheme could be devised to get over this difficulty. I hope the Minister will accept some responsibility in this matter. Many of the schools concerned were encouraged to join a scheme which they could not afford and many of them are regretting it now.
Progress reported; Committee to sit again.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers. - Unemployment Situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he has received any deputation on the unemployment situation over the past two months; and, if so, the number of deputations received and the areas represented.

There have been no meetings with formal deputations on the matter during the period mentioned in the question. I have, however, received representations on the subject, and there have been informal discussions with various interests involved. Other members of the Government have also had discussions in relation to aspects with which they are concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: In view of the mounting figures of unemployment and the possibility that, with a deterioration in the Anglo-Irish position from the point of view of trade, our figure of unemployed may reach the 100,000 mark, does the Taoiseach think it advisable to have a general meeting with the unions as soon as possible on the entire unemployment situation to see if any short term improvement can be effected?

Yes, I had such a meeting in prospect, and because the Congress were busily engaged up to the present time in connection with a meeting they are holding today, they asked me to leave it until after today to have a meeting on this subject.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Does the Taoiseach foresee the possibility that, if there is a further deterioration in Anglo-Irish relations, shortly there will be an unemployment figure of 100,000?

I would not like to predict that the unemployment figure will reach 100,000. I certainly hope it will not, but nobody can deny that, as a result of the present circumstances there is an economic situation generally which could effect the unemployment position. We are taking full account of that situation.

Is the Taoiseach aware that the figure for manufacturing industry published this morning showed that for the latest quarter for which figures are available there is a drop of 3,500 in employment by comparison with the same period last year? Would he agree, therefore, that there is a necessity to stimulate economic growth so that this decline in employment which is causing by no means all but certainly part of the rise in unemployment would be dealt with? Is the Taoiseach satisfied that measures taken to date to stimulate economic growth have been sufficient for this purpose?

Some of the measures taken, the most recent ones particularly, have not yet had their effect in stimulating employment, but I can assure the Deputy that the Government are keeping in touch with the situation and will take action wherever possible and in whatever manner possible.

Would the Taoiseach not agree that the fact that the measures taken have not yet taken effect, which shows that the measures were taken too late, is another reason for acting sooner rather than later?
No, I do not agree. The unemployment figures, as indicated yesterday by the Minister for Finance, are declining as of now.
Will the Taoiseach not agree that a seasonal decline does not prove anything about the underlying trend?
I am not going to deny the seasonality of the situation. That applies in every figure we get.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers. - Northern Ireland Situation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach whether the Government has given any consideration to the effect on opinion abroad of news reports of Northern events by British news media; and whether any course of action has been decided on.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if, in view of the apparent acceptance by British news media of Army versions of Northern events, any consideration has been given to the establishment of a News Agency which would give a truthful account of Northern news.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Begley Mr. Begley Mr. G. Lynch Mr. G. Lynch
Speaker.P: and Mr. Begley asked the Taoiseach if, in order to acquaint the maximum number of people with the true position at present obtaining in Northern Ireland, he is prepared to consider the re-establishment of the Irish News Agency.

asked the Taoiseach if he is satisfied that the efforts of the Government to counter massive British propaganda with regard to the Derry killings was effective; and if he will indicate whether or not Markpress advised on this matter.
With your permission, a Cheann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 2, 3, 4 and 5 together.

I am well aware of the importance of British and world opinion in regard to events in the North of Ireland. Although we may at times find that the coverage or comment in foreign news media is less satisfactory than we would wish, I believe that in general there is a wide realisation abroad of the basic facts of the situation as well as the urgent need for changes in the North and the need to move to a political solution. In regard to the events in Derry, in particular, the reports available to me confirm that world press and public opinion has in general been strongly critical of the actions of the British Army.
The Government's information services here and abroad are very active in making the facts of the situation known. Their efforts are being supplemented by the public relations services of Markpress.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: In view of the importance of an informed British public opinion which would, in turn, influence the Health Government and in view of the deliberately misleading reports which have been put out in particular in relation to the Derry incidents from British Army sources and which have been taken over uncritically by the British media, and also in view of the misleading British reports relayed in the United States which have an effect on public opinion there, would he agree it is important for the people of this part of the country to establish an agency which would put out, we would hope, a fair estimate of the events in Northern Ireland and thus help towards the political solution which is so necessary?

I do not think an agency is necessary for that purpose. I agree entirely and I admit candidly that we must improve the news service from this country and certainly improve knowledge of the facts rather than make propaganda. That is the purpose of what we are doing at the present time. I do not think we should go as far as establishing a specific press agency for that purpose at this stage.

As one formerly connected with an Irish news agency when we had one here, I should like to ask the Taoiseach whether he would consider consulting with representatives of the national newspapers of, I would hope, the entire island, at least those who would be prepared to join in such consultation, to consider the question of whether a national newsagency based on the press and other news media of this country could be established. I make the suggestion having regard to the fact that the weakness of the former Irish News Agency was that it was formed by the Government fiat alone and without consultation or without adequate consultation, I believe, with the newspapers. Would the Taoiseach consider at least consulting with the press and other media to see whether the time might now be ripe for some such an agency?

In the event of the establishment of such an agency I would certainly be in favour of seeking assistance and technical advice from the best possible sources, and I will admit the best sources would be in the established news media in this country. If that eventuality arises I certainly would consider that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: Would the Taoiseach agree that the events in Northern Ireland are being misrepresented by British Army sources?
I have seen evidence of gross misrepresentation of the situation in Derry as we know the events there.

Arising out of the Taoiseach's reply to Deputy Cruise-O'Brien's question, would he not agree that it would be useful for him to have consultations at this stage with the editors of the national newspapers on the general question of the dissemination outside the country of the truth about events here, without prejudice to any particular solution? Would he not agree that his reply tended to defer the issue a little until somebody came up with something, and that a general consultation might yield useful ideas from people who are perpetually involved?

Deputy Cruise-O'Brien's question, as I understood it, envisaged the establishment of a news agency, in the event of the estabilishment of which he counselled that we ought to consult the technicians in this country, if I may call them that. I have said already I did not think it was necessary to do that yet. I have not come to the conclusion that it is. I am sure that when the eventuality arises that we would consider the establishment of an agency, certainly I would consult——

Have the Government taken any steps to disseminate to people in Britain as widely as possible copies of the factual newspaper reports by journalists about Derry. I do not suggest the Government send any propaganda material, but I want to know whether anything has been done to bring together the reports of the British and foreign journalists of what actually happened, the eye-witness accounts, the excellent account in the Times of the following Tuesday which itself incorporated eye-witness accounts, and the remarkable reconstructions of events in the Sunday Press, the Sunday Independent and on RTE. Would the Taoiseach consider it would be desirable that these be brought together, simply as factual statements, with no propaganda attached to them, and disseminated as widely as possible to people in Britain who clearly have not understood the truth of what happened there and who may not discover the truth of what has happened there from the Widgery Tribunal?
That is a good suggestion and I shall have a look at it.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers. - Northern Ireland Situation Talks.

Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he has considered having talks with members of the Unionist Party or of the Democratic Unionist Party of Northern Ireland; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

I have under continuing consideration all possible steps which might help in the situation. I have, however, no immediate plans for entering into talks of the kind referred to nor have I received any approach for such talks.

In view of the fact that a solution to the Irish problem cannot take place until talks are held with the parties named in the question and in view of the fact that the longer a solution is delayed the more lives are going to be lost, would the Taoiseach not, as a gesture of reconciliation and as an act of initiative on the part of the Government here, take steps to initiate those talks?

I do not think those talks would be fruitful at this stage in advance of a political initiative on the part of the British Government. We are led to believe that something like that is about to come. If I felt generally that that could put forward the situation at this time I would be prepared to consider it, but I do not think it would.
Can the Taoiseach give any indication of what type of initiative he expects from the British Government which will obviate the need for these talks?
Whatever it is I hope it will come soon.
How soon? People are dying every day.
If these people were prepared to speak to the Taoiseach, would he receive them for talks?
I have seen different people from time to time and some of these may well represent the point of view referred to in Deputy Cooney's question. I have no objection to seeing them at any time.
Is the Taoiseach saying he met people——
In other words, is it clear to the people from Northern Ireland that the Taoiseach would welcome talks with them?
I would, of course, with anybody.
Is the Taoiseach saying he met people from Northern Ireland and he is not sure whether they represent these parties?

I have met individuals. I do not ask them for their membership cards of any organisation as long as I feel they are genuine people seeking a solution to the problem. I do not know what organisations they might have been members of.
Would the Taoiseach not be curious to know?
I would have a good idea in most cases.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers. - Role of European Parliaments.

Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach what action he proposes to take with a view to formulating proposals acceptable to the political parties in Dáil Éireann for the enhancement of the role of the European Parliament referred to in his speech on the occasion of his signing the accession Treaty at the EEC.

We shall be participating in the discussions, which, it is expected, will be held among the ten countries concerned, on, among other matters, the question of the role of the European Parliament in the enlarged Communities. I shall be prepared to consider, at the appropriate time, the views of the other political parties in the House on this question in the context of our participation in the discussions.
Any change in the role or structure of the European Parliament will, of course, be a matter for decision by the member States of the enlarged Communities.

Would the Taoiseach not agree that some time ago the Minister for Foreign Affairs told this House that this was a matter for the Dáil, not for the Government? Would he indicate how the Dáil can come to grips with the question and have a discussion out of which might emerge an Irish viewpoint on this matter? I am not clear as to what the correct procedure is so that we may have a debate and come to a conclusion on it.

We will be having the debate on the White Paper on accession during this term. The meeting I referred to, the summit meeting, will certainly not take place before that debate, so from that debate ought to emerge the viewpoint of all Deputies.

Would the Taoiseach not agree that we are dealing with the very specific problem of the powers of the European Parliament and the desirability of direct elections. This is something which will get lost in the maelstrom of a White Paper debate which will be very much a pro and con EEC membership debate, I am afraid. Will he not agree that it is desirable for us to have some special debate on this subject before the summit conference, so that the Taoiseach may have the concerted mind of the House on this issue before he goes to this meeting? Would he consider that?
Yes, but I think that might be better achieved by consultation between the parties.
Does the Taoiseach agree that it is a matter for the Dáil?
At the moment it is a matter for the Dáil to decide on the procedures for election or selection of the people to go to the assembly.

The Taoiseach misunderstands. The question to which the Minister for Foreign Affairs was replying related to the changing of the method of election to the European Parliament and changing its powers. He said that was a matter for the Dáil. How can the Dáil formulate a view for the Taoiseach to bring with him to the summit meeting on behalf of the Dáil? It will not be formulated during the debate on the White Paper. I submit to the Taoiseach that, possibly with preliminary consultations between the Whips, a debate on this subject should be organised before the summit takes place and after the debate on the White Paper.
I will consider that.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers. - Water Fluoridation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he intends to re-examine the position regarding the fluoridation of water in view of the increasing concern throughout the world as to its effects.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Childers) Erskine Hamilton Childers
Speaker.P: I am not aware that there is increasing concern throughout the world about the effects of fluoridation of water supplies. On the contrary, there is growing evidence to show the safety and effectiveness of the measure as a means of inhibiting dental decay.
I do not consider that there are any grounds which would justify my reexamining policy on the fluoridation of public water supplies in this country.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry
Speaker.P: Everybody agrees on its beneficial effects in arresting dental decay, but the Swedish Parliament recently repealed their laws allowing fluoridation and there is a considerable and growing body of opinion in America and Great Britain that there are other side effects. Even though they admit that it has a beneficial effect on teeth they say there are other side effects of which we are not yet fully aware.

We have had the teeth of a great number of children examined and we found no side effects arising from fluoridation. I rely on the World Health Organisation inquiry into this. They said that a given part of fluoride per million parts of water is entirely safe.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers. - Content of Detergents.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if standards enforced in relation to the content of detergents allow the presence of nitrilotriacetic acid; if any detergents containing this acid are at present on sale in this country; and if any studies have been made on the effect of this acid on health or the environment.

There are no legal standards for detergents in this country. As far as my Department can ascertain there are no detergents containing nitrilotriacetic acid on sale in Ireland. It is understood that some studies on the use of nitrilotriacetic acid in detergents have been carried out in the USA.
Does the Minister not consider it rather unwise that there are no standards in this country for detergents?

I had better refer the Deputy to the questions I have already answered in the Dáil on dermatitis arising from detergents. I have not had any complaints in my Department either from consultants or people that there is any grave danger attaching to the use of detergents except in regard to their pollution effect and that is a matter for the Minister for Local Government in relation to the general control of pollution.

Is it not the case that standards are enforced by the European Economic Community on the contents of detergents? Does the Minister consider that accession to the Community would involve a change in our law?
I would have to look into that.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers. - Repatriation of Assets.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance whether repatriation of assets held abroad for investment in the home economy is under consideration, in view of the decrease in foreign investment in the economy.

There is no evidence that a decline in the inflow of capital has hindered industrial or other basic development. Indeed, there was an exceptionally high inflow of funds in 1971 and, while this may not be repeated in the present year, the indications are that there is still a substantial inflow. Apart from this, Irish banks have resources to enable them to lend more money for sound productive investment if the demand should be forthcoming.
With the background as indicated, the question of special action to secure the repatriation of Irish-owned assets abroad does not arise.

The matter has been examined, however, from time to time. Assets held abroad can be divided between those held by companies and individuals and those held by the banking system, in particular by the Central Bank. In the case of assets held by companies and individuals, it is not apparent how such assets could be effectively repatriated except on a voluntary basis. Attempts to achieve this by other means would be difficult if not impossible to implement successfully and could easily discourage foreign investment in this country in the future. The foreign assets of the Central Bank are the country's official external reserves and, of course, they are held to finance any adverse development in external payments. The question of repatriation does not arise in the case of the Associated Banks and non-Associated Banks as they are no longer in a net foreign asset position.

MainHeading.P: It should, of course, be remembered that our foreign investments earn a valuable income for the country.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: In regard to the part of the Minister's answer about there being no evidence to suggest that there was any dimunition in the amount of foreign investment in this country, could the Minister give any further information to the House about the evidence which suggests that there has been no let-up in the inflow of investment?

The inflow for 1971 was, as I said, exceptionally high. This was partially distorted by the bank strike but, leaving that aside, the indications so far in the current year are that there is a substantial inflow still going on. I would not expect that the inflow this year would be as high as last year for the reasons I have mentioned. Nevertheless, as of now there is no indication of any difficulty in this regard. The indications are that the inflow is still substantial.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. O'Leary Mr. M. O'Leary
Speaker.P: There is no evidence of any withdrawal of investment already planned?
No, there is not at the moment.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers. - Agricultural Show Societies.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Timmins Mr. Timmins Mr. Fox Mr. Fox
Speaker.P: and Mr. Timmins asked the Minister for Finance if he is aware that tax demands are being made on agricultural show societies and if, in view of the adverse effect of such demands, he will exempt such societies from taxation.

Agricultural societies are exempt from income tax in respect of any profit or gains arising from an exhibition or show held for the purposes of the society. They are, however, liable to tax in the ordinary way in respect of income from other sources received by them, for example, investment income. This position has not been altered since 1925.

I understand from the Revenue Commissioners that, in practice, the great majority of agricultural societies are not liable for any tax, and in the exceptional case where liability arises it rarely amounts to more than £50.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers. - Tax-Free Petrol.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. P. Barry Mr. P. Barry

The answer is as follows:

If spoons are made of precious metal or rolled precious metal they are classified at heading 71.13 of the customs and excise tariff, even if coins are mounted on them. If such spoons are made of base metal they are classified at heading 82.14 (A). The rates of duty chargeable at these headings are as follows (the percentage rates are relative to the value of the goods):—

row.entry: 20% plus 60% or £0.02 each, whichever is the greater
20% plus 40% or £0.0134 each, whichever is the greater
20% plus 40% or £0.0134 each, whichever is the greater
8% plus 16% or £0.0053 each, whichever is the greater
8% plus 16% or £0.0053 each, whichever is the greater

Christmas releases are either temporary releases over the Christmas period or outright release in advance of the date on which the sentences would otherwise expire. The questions relate to these outright releases and I shall confine my reply to them.

Certain other offenders who would be due for release within a couple of weeks after Christmas also have their sentences reviewed at the same time and, in particular instances, if there are good grounds for terminating sentences, they may be discharged as well.
Beyond saying that all cases are fully considered, I could not agree to discuss the considerations relating to a decision taken in any particular instance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan) Mr. T.J. Fitzpatrick (Cavan)

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions Oral Answers. - Mountjoy Female Prisoners.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M. Dockrell Mr. M. Dockrell
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if his attention has been drawn to a series of articles (details supplied) concerning the treatment of female prisoners in Mountjoy Jail; if he is aware of the unease caused by these statements in the public mind; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
I am glad of the opportunity presented by this question to put on the record some facts in relation to the publication of these newspaper articles about Mountjoy Female Prison.

MainHeading.P: On 30th December the writer of the articles informed the Government Information Bureau that, in an interview with her, a number of ex-prisoners had made allegations about conditions in Mountjoy. She stated that, to give the officials a chance to reply, she wanted permission to have an appointment with the matron of the prison, permission to visit the prison and an appointment with the chairman of the visiting committee. She was informed that a visiting committee is an independent body and that any application to interview a representative of the body could be made direct. As regards the other requests, she was informed that I was responsible for dealing with complaints and that, if they were to be dealt with, I would, of course, need, as a first step, to know what they were. In a reply from the writer received by the Bureau on 5th January she submitted seven questions. She was reminded of what she had already said and of the fact that the allegations had not yet been conveyed. It was also mentioned that a great deal of the other information in which she appeared to be interested could be obtained in various published documents, which were specified.

A further letter and enclosure—a five-page document containing a list of 13 detailed questions—were received in my Department late on the evening of Friday, 14th January. The fact that this material would take time to deal with was recognised by the writer herself, as she asked for an estimate of how long it would take. A week later, on Friday morning, 21st January, a further seven queries of a statistical character were received. That afternoon three further queries were received, the answers to which would also involve a good deal of work. At that point also it was stated on behalf of the newspaper that the publication of the articles that were planned would begin on the following Monday and a reply was sought before then.

A reply was issued that evening. It pointed out that the writer's letter and enclosure had been received in the Department shortly before the office was due to close on Friday, 14th January and that several, if not most, of the 13 items listed in the five-page document obviously could be dealt with only after checking with the Governor who in turn obviously would have to check with the prison staff; that each of these officers had his or her ordinary work to do and could not set that work aside; that, likewise, the staff in the Department headquarters had their commitments and priority had to be given to those matters that need to be dealt with urgently—including prison administration work; that a week had been quite inadequate to enable a reply to be prepared, quite apart from the fact that on that very day a further ten questions had been submitted. It was further pointed out in the reply that when allegations are made that would, if established, involve a clear breach by prison staff of any important rule— for instance, an allegation that the prisoner was kicked, punched and had her hair pulled—the normal way, and the only satisfactory way, in which to have the matter investigated was to supply particulars that would enable alleged incidents to be checked; that no such details had been supplied; and that it had been taken for granted, when the writer said that she wished to give an opportunity for reply to the allegations, that she would supply enough details to enable them to be checked out.

My Department's reply went on to say that, since apparently a reasonable opportunity was not to be given to reply more effectively, all that could be said was that allegations of beating, et cetera, were flatly denied by the prison staff; that no such allegations had been made to the Governor or to the Visiting Committee or individual members thereof; and that any suggestion that prisoners were afraid to complain was disproved by the fact that complaints of one kind or another were freely made.

The reply then dealt with one specific complaint that alleged that a portion of cabbage served to a prisoner contained 86 insects. It said that the original complaint related to very small objects which the prisoner claimed she had seen move, that is to say, live insects. Nobody in the prison service could suggest how such alleged insects could survive cooking or suggest why no other prisoner found similar ones. Since the complaint was not made until some hours after the meal was over, they found it even more difficult to get to the bottom of the incident.

The reply to the newspaper concluded by saying that, if it was intended to publicise allegations of this kind, on the word of people who in many cases are wholly opposed to anybody who to them represents authority, allegations which in the nature of things can never be wholly disproved, I wished to be taken as entering a strong protest. I think it regrettable, to say the least, that allegations should be published without any indication whatsoever of the substance of the communications that had passed between the newspaper and my Department. I am aware that, subsequent to the publication of the articles, the author of them has, in letters to the same newspaper, made references in general terms to the fact that she had been in touch with the Department. She did not give details, however, and what she said was inaccurate, as a comparison between the factual account I have given and what she has said will show.

It is quite clear that these allegations were published without providing any genuine opportunity beforehand either to deny or to comment on them and that what purported to be an offer of an opportunity to comment was made in such a way as to imply that it was for the newspaper rather than for me to nominate who should speak for me. I am not prepared to go along with that. Neither am I prepared to accept that, in relation to unchecked allegations from questionable sources, it is sufficient for a newspaper to be willing to provide space for a reply after the publication has already taken place and that it would be appropriate or in the public interest for me to reply in that fashion.

I will, however, say for the information of this House that the allegations, like all allegations, will be— and, in fact, are already being—investigated in so far as it is possible to do so on the basis of the published material. While I would not prejudge the result of the investigation of any particular allegation, I am quite satisfied that, taking the allegations as a whole, they present a gross distortion of the position in the female prison. They amount, of course, to a serious reflection on the prison staff, and not just on the system, and have been so interpreted by the staff who have expressed to me personally their strong resentment, a resentment which is all the more understandable when the number of staff is so small that allegations of this kind hurt each one personally. I, therefore, am glad to take this opportunity to say publicly that I am in no doubt that the staff of this prison are not as they are depicted in these articles but, on the contrary, that they deserve the praise that has been given to them from many disinterested quarters.

It is, of course, true that the prison itself is old and unsatisfactory. One of my first official acts as Minister for Justice was to decide that steps should be taken to acquire a suitable site for a new prison. Three sites have, each in turn, since been considered for acquisition but for a variety of reasons, none of them proved suitable on full consideration. However, as I indicated recently, I now have good reason to believe that a suitable site will be available in the very near future.

I should add that several months ago special measures were taken to re-equip the kitchens in all our prisons and also in Saint Patrick's Institution and in Shanganagh Castle. A new kitchen has, in fact, since been provided for the women prisoners and is now in operation. Apart from facilitating the better preparation and serving of food, it will have the important benefit of providing facilities for teaching basic cooking skills to the many prisoners who had not themselves the opportunity to acquire them.
